Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Multi-Element Illuminication for Mobile Free-Space-Optical Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
As anyone who has used WiFi in urban environments knows, there is interference between multiple competing users and loss of throughput. Wireless home networks are not just for casual web browsing, but are also being used to stream high-quality video to tablets and other portable devices. Interference between access points degrades the user experience for these applications. One method being proposed to address the increased demand for high-capacity local-area wireless networking is Free-space-optical communication (FSOC). In parallel, solid-state lighting (SSL) devices with multiple light emitting diodes (LEDs) are being deployed and commercialized due to their superior durability and energy efficency. Though stemming from the same core optoelectronics technology, SSL and FSOC have inherent tradeoffs: the illuminated area is larger when the divergence angle of the optoelectronic transmitter is high, whereas the transmission range is longer when it is small. This project envisions multi-element "illuminication" modules that perform joint and adaptive optimization of two conflicting goals: illumination and communication. Such modules and protocols are potentially deployable in many settings such as residential and commercial buildings, airplanes, and other RF-limited environments.

This projects is developing a framework to design, optimize and test illumination-communication technologies considering needs and requirements for both functionalities. To attain mobile illuminication with high spatial reuse and throughput, and uniformly high illuminance; the project designs (i) multi-element illuminication modules which uses spherical structures for spatial reuse and uniform illumination, (ii) adaptive intensity control for energy saving and chromacity control over red-green-blue LEDs, (iii) transceivers with varying field-of-view and divergence angle, (iv) automatic realignment protocols using electronic steering and focusing for mobility, (v) cognitive algorithms for transceiver selection, and (vi) optical wireless localization with high accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent proliferation of wireless technologies and choices available to user applications has triggered a tremendous wireless demand, and the wireless devıces are expected to dominate the Internet soon. The availability of wireless resources has caused an ever-increasing variety of applications, such as mobile data, wireless peer-to-peer and sensor networks. Recent reports show that usage of mobile web and WiFi by smartphones is increasing sharply, with more than 80% of their data consumption landing on WiFi points. However, radio frequency (RF) based wireless technologies (WiFi, LTE etc.) have only limited bandwidth which will soon not be enough to respond the fast increasing demand. Hence, we urgently need innovations that will enable leveraging of new wireless spectrums in order to respond to the exploding mobile wireless traffic demand.

 

In this project, we used the unique advantages of the emerging lighting technologies (i.e. Light Emitting Diodes ? LEDs) to use visible light for high-speed wireless data transmission. These technologies are provably superior to the existing lighting technologies due to their durability and efficiency as well as fast turn-on and turn-off properties that can be leveraged for a new type wireless communication called Visible Light communication (VLC). Overarching goal of the project was to investigate and develop multi-element "illuminication" structures that perform joint and adaptive optimization of two goals: illumination and communication.

 

Throughout the project, we investigated how a better coverage in a wider area could be attained by ?beam steering?, developed techniques to optimize VLC wireless service to many mobile/stationary users in different scenarios including random location and, orientation of the receiver, built several prototype VLC wireless access points using commercial off-the-shelf components. We also explored use of piezoelectric actuators and spatial light modulators such as Digital Micromirror Devices (DMD) for steering of visible light beams without impacting the illumination to improve the spatial reuse and significantly increase aggregate throughput in a VLC system. This technology allows for the simultaneous communications from one VLC transmitter to several receivers and for the continuous tracking of moving receivers within the projection grid of the system.

 

The illuminication protocols and modules developed in this study have a great potential of implementation and deployment in a wide range of settings, including but not limited to residential and commercial buildings, military and other high security environments. The protocols further could be included in future communication standards developed by IEEE and other governing bodies. The envisioned modules could be adopted by architects, designers, civil and electrical engineers in the building industry for the future "carbon neutral" or "net-zero" buildings. Throughout the project 3 graduate students and 11 undergraduate students supported and an additional 10 undergraduate students involved with the research. Some of the undergraduate students developed working prototype VLC modules as a part of their senior design projects. The project resulted 1 US patent, 9 papers published in peer-reviewed scientific journals and 9 conference presentations.
